title: Will Ukraine join NATO before 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2030, Ukraine is officially invited to join NATO and the invitation is accepted by the Ukrainian government. The invitation must be documented in an official NATO communiqué or similar authoritative source. Additionally, the acceptance must be confirmed by a public statement from the President of Ukraine or the Ukrainian government. The resolution will also consider the status of Ukraine's membership in NATO if it has completed all necessary reforms and met the criteria for membership as outlined in NATO's Membership Action Plan. Any temporary or conditional invitations that do not lead to full membership by the specified date do not count towards a Yes resolution.

title: Will a Formula 1 Grand Prix be hosted in a country currently under international sanctions by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, a Formula 1 Grand Prix is officially scheduled to take place in a country that is currently under international sanctions imposed by recognized authorities such as the United Nations, the European Union, or the United States. The term 'international sanctions' refers to restrictions imposed on a country by the international community, which may include trade restrictions, financial embargoes, and travel bans. The hosting of the Grand Prix must be confirmed by an official announcement from Formula 1 or the relevant governing body. If the event is canceled or relocated for any reason, this question will resolve as No. Temporary or unofficial races do not count towards this resolution.

title: Will the US Senate pass significant legislation regarding nuclear safety standards by 2025?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the United States Senate has passed legislation that significantly alters or establishes new nuclear safety standards. Significant legislation is defined as any bill that: 
- Introduces new safety regulations for nuclear power plants, including but not limited to operational, environmental, or safety protocols. 
- Amends existing laws such as the Atomic Energy Act or the Nuclear Waste Policy Act in a way that enhances safety standards. 
The legislation must be officially signed into law by the President of the United States. The resolution will rely on official congressional records and reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) for verification. If multiple bills are introduced, at least one must be passed and signed into law for the resolution to be Yes.

title: Will the European Union implement a unified nuclear waste management policy by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the European Union has officially implemented a unified nuclear waste management policy that is recognized and adopted by all member states. The policy must include standardized procedures for the handling, storage, and disposal of nuclear waste across the EU, and it must be formally adopted through a legislative process involving the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union. The implementation must be confirmed by an official EU announcement or documentation. In the absence of such an announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, Reuters, Bloomberg, New York Times, Washington Post) are sufficient to confirm the policy's adoption. Temporary measures or pilot programs do not count towards this question's resolution.

title: Will the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams lead to a significant increase in global soccer viewership by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, there is clear evidence of a significant increase in global soccer viewership attributed to the FIFA World Cup's expansion to 48 teams. Specifically, this will be measured by: 1. An increase of at least 20% in the average global viewership numbers for the World Cup compared to the previous tournament with 32 teams in 2018. 2. Official reports from FIFA or credible third-party sources (such as Nielsen or similar audience measurement organizations) confirming this increase. 3. The increase must be directly linked to the expanded format, meaning that viewership figures must show a correlation with the expansion and not be influenced by other factors (e.g., the popularity of specific teams or players). In the absence of clear data from FIFA, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, etc.) will suffice to confirm the increase.

title: Will South Korea become the leader in global digital governance by 2030?
body:
This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, South Korea is recognized as the leader in global digital governance based on the following criteria: 
- South Korea must have implemented comprehensive digital governance policies that are adopted and followed by at least 75% of its population, as verified by government reports and independent surveys. 
- South Korea must hold a prominent position in international digital governance forums, such as the OECD and G20, where it leads discussions and initiatives on digital policy, cybersecurity, and data privacy. 
- The country must be acknowledged in at least three reputable international reports or rankings (e.g., by the World Economic Forum, UN, or similar organizations) as the top nation in digital governance practices. 
- Significant collaborations or partnerships with at least three other countries in establishing global digital standards must be in place, with documented agreements and initiatives. 
In the absence of clear consensus, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will Microsoft's carbon negative pledge significantly impact global CO2 levels by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, credible evidence demonstrates that Microsoft's carbon negative pledge has led to a measurable reduction in global CO2 levels. The reduction must be at least 1% of global CO2 emissions compared to levels recorded in 2020, as reported by authoritative sources such as the Global Carbon Project or the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). The impact must be attributed directly to Microsoft's initiatives and not to other external factors or global events. The evidence must be supported by peer-reviewed research or official reports from reputable organizations (e.g., UN, World Resources Institute) that analyze the effectiveness of corporate carbon pledges on global emissions.

title: Will a breakthrough in physics lead to a new form of clean energy by 2040?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2040, a scientifically validated breakthrough in physics is announced that leads to a new form of clean energy. The criteria for a 'breakthrough' includes: 1. The discovery or theoretical development must be published in a peer-reviewed scientific journal. 2. The new energy form must be capable of being harnessed for practical use, demonstrated through experimental evidence or prototypes. 3. The clean energy must significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions compared to current energy sources and be scalable for widespread use. 4. The breakthrough must be recognized by a consensus of leading physicists and energy experts, as indicated by endorsements from reputable scientific organizations or institutions. If the breakthrough is announced but not yet operational or scalable, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will the World Health Organization declare a global health emergency due to climate-related diseases by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, the World Health Organization (WHO) officially declares a global health emergency specifically related to diseases that are directly attributable to climate change. The declaration must be made in a formal statement or report from the WHO and must identify specific diseases that are exacerbated by climate change, such as vector-borne diseases (e.g., malaria, dengue), respiratory diseases (e.g., asthma, allergies), and waterborne diseases (e.g., cholera). The declaration should be based on scientific evidence and consensus from the global health community, including input from epidemiologists and climate scientists. The resolution will not count declarations that are vague or general in nature without specific reference to climate-related diseases.

title: Will India become a global leader in quantum computing by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, India is recognized as a global leader in quantum computing based on the following criteria: 1. India must have established a significant number of operational quantum computing facilities that are recognized internationally, with at least 5 facilities being operational and producing quantum computing solutions. 2. India must have made substantial contributions to quantum computing research, with at least 50 peer-reviewed publications in top-tier journals and conferences acknowledged by the quantum computing community. 3. India must have developed and deployed quantum computing applications that are utilized by industry and government, demonstrating practical use cases. 4. Recognition by authoritative sources such as the International Quantum Computing Association or similar organizations, stating India's leadership position in the global quantum computing landscape. If these criteria are not met by the specified date, the question will resolve as No.

title: Will a major breakthrough in COVID-19 vaccine development be achieved through the use of artificial intelligence by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, an artificial intelligence (AI) system is publicly credited with a major breakthrough in the development of a COVID-19 vaccine. A 'major breakthrough' is defined as either: (1) the identification of a new vaccine candidate that demonstrates at least 70% efficacy in clinical trials, or (2) the development of a novel approach or technology that significantly accelerates vaccine development timelines and is recognized by the scientific community. The breakthrough must be reported and confirmed by at least two reputable news sources (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) and acknowledged by a relevant health authority such as the World Health Organization (WHO) or the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). This question resolves as No if no such breakthrough is achieved by the specified date.

title: Will Australia launch its own sovereign satellite navigation system by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, Australia has officially launched and made operational its own sovereign satellite navigation system that is independent of foreign systems. The system must be capable of providing positioning, navigation, and timing services across Australia and its surrounding regions. The launch must be confirmed by an official government announcement or documentation from the Australian Space Agency or a similar authoritative body. The system must not rely on any foreign satellite systems for its core operations. Any partial systems or trials will not count; the system must be fully operational and available for public and governmental use.

title: Will machine learning algorithms surpass human accuracy in predicting consumer behavior by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, machine learning algorithms demonstrate a statistically significant improvement in accuracy over human predictions in consumer behavior across multiple large-scale studies. The studies must be published in reputable peer-reviewed journals and involve diverse datasets representative of various consumer markets. The accuracy of machine learning algorithms must exceed that of human experts by at least 10% in terms of predictive accuracy, measured through metrics such as AUC-ROC, precision, recall, or F1 score. The resolution will rely on consensus from the academic and industry experts in the field, and the results must be corroborated by independent validation from at least two credible sources, such as major academic institutions or industry research organizations.

title: Will the Democratic Party (US) implement a policy to significantly boost technology startups by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, the Democratic Party (US) has officially implemented a policy that includes specific measures aimed at significantly boosting technology startups. Such measures must include at least one of the following: 1) A substantial increase in federal funding for technology startup grants or loans, defined as at least $1 billion allocated within a year; 2) Introduction of tax incentives for technology startups that result in at least a 20% increase in new startups within the following year; 3) Creation of new regulatory frameworks that reduce barriers for technology startups, confirmed by a reputable source such as the White House or a major news organization (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times). The policy must be officially announced and enacted, and temporary measures or pilot programs do not count unless they are part of a larger, sustainable policy framework.

title: Will North Korea undergo a major legal reform by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, North Korea has implemented significant legal reforms that are officially announced and enacted by the government. A 'major legal reform' is defined as any substantial change to the legal framework that affects the rights of citizens or the structure of governance, including but not limited to reforms in criminal law, civil rights, or administrative law. The reforms must be recognized by credible international observers, including reports from reputable news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) and should demonstrate a shift towards greater legal rights or protections for individuals. The absence of reforms or minor adjustments that do not significantly alter the legal landscape will result in a resolution of No.

title: Will a significant international climate change treaty be ratified by 2030?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2030, a significant international climate change treaty is ratified by at least 100 countries, including major emitters such as the United States, China, and members of the European Union. A significant treaty is defined as one that includes legally binding commitments to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, with specific targets and timelines that are recognized by the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). The treaty must be officially announced and documented by the UNFCCC or a similar authoritative body. In the absence of a UN announcement, credible reports from at least three major news organizations (BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post) will suffice. If a treaty is ratified but later withdrawn or significantly altered, it will not count towards the resolution.

title: Will Amazon's market share in the global e-commerce sector exceed 50% by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, Amazon's market share in the global e-commerce sector exceeds 50%. Market share will be determined based on the total gross merchandise value (GMV) of e-commerce transactions worldwide, as reported by reputable industry analysts such as eMarketer or Statista. The data must be sourced from reports published no later than January 2026. In case of conflicting reports, the resolution will rely on the most credible source that meets the aforementioned criteria.

title: Will a major technology company face a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government before 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, before January 1, 2025, a major technology company (defined as a company with a market capitalization exceeding $10 billion) is officially subjected to a landmark ethics investigation by the United States government. The investigation must be publicly announced by a recognized government agency, such as the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) or the Department of Justice (DOJ), and must pertain to significant ethical concerns, including but not limited to data privacy, anti-competitive practices, or consumer protection issues. A 'landmark' investigation is characterized by its scope, impact, and public interest, and must be covered by at least three major news organizations (e.g., BBC, The Guardian, New York Times, Washington Post). Investigations that are routine or part of standard regulatory practices do not count towards this resolution.

title: Will SpaceX's Starship enable the commercialization of space travel by 2025?
body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by December 31, 2025, SpaceX's Starship has successfully completed at least one commercial spaceflight that includes paying customers traveling to space. The flight must be publicly announced and confirmed by SpaceX, and must include a minimum of three paying customers on board. The commercial flight should be defined as a trip where passengers are charged for the experience of traveling to space, not including test flights or government-sponsored missions. The flight must reach an altitude of at least 100 kilometers (the Kármán line), which is internationally recognized as the boundary of space.
